text:
I plan to teach a colleague Julia, but we no longer share an office…
Has anyone tried using Microsoft's "Live Share" VSCode extension to do "Pair Programming" in Julia, or as a lock-down teaching aide?
If so, would you recommend it versus simply using Zoom?

elements.text:
I plan to teach a colleague Julia, but we no longer share an office…
Has anyone tried using Microsoft's "Live Share" VSCode extension to do "Pair Programming" in Julia, or as a lock-down teaching aide?
If so, would you recommend it versus simply using Zoom?

text: I tried using it for pair programming and it's pretty cool! However some stuff is missing. For example, the plots pane is not visible for the other one. Also I was the only one running commands in the end, but I don't think the other guy tried. Also if you use the Web interface you cannot have the Julia extension installed and therefore no highlighting and co

elements.text: I tried using it for pair programming and it's pretty cool! However some stuff is missing. For example, the plots pane is not visible for the other one. Also I was the only one running commands in the end, but I don't think the other guy tried. Also if you use the Web interface you cannot have the Julia extension installed and therefore no highlighting and co

text: Interesting, thanks. I was experimenting with it yesterday. Was able to share the desktop version of VS code from my laptop to my desktop (not using the web interface I think). I could see that code windows and the REPL got shared nicely but didn't try plots.

elements.text: Interesting, thanks. I was experimenting with it yesterday. Was able to share the desktop version of VS code from my laptop to my desktop (not using the web interface I think). I could see that code windows and the REPL got shared nicely but didn't try plots.

text: I had the same experience - pretty cool, but lack of plots is pretty sad

elements.text: I had the same experience - pretty cool, but lack of plots is pretty sad

text: definitely better than only zoom, since you can have them do some typing, but you can jump in if you need to do something fast

elements.text: definitely better than only zoom, since you can have them do some typing, but you can jump in if you need to do something fast

text: Haha - like being a driving instructor in need of an emergency brake!

elements.text: Haha - like being a driving instructor in need of an emergency brake!

text: Which version are you referring to with "web interface"? I think it does work with GitHub Codespaces with the Julia extension?

elements.text: Which version are you referring to with "web interface"? I think it does work with GitHub Codespaces with the Julia extension?

text: I wasn't quite sure what <@U7QLM6E2E> was referring to by "web interface". When I experimented with Live Share, user A generates a hyperlink that they send to user B, who clicks on the hyperlink in an email. That causes the desktop version of VSCode to launch on user B's machine. Then users A and user B both have desktop VSCode and can both see what each other is up to. Seems great but I haven't tried it with an actual "student". And for me, A was me on my laptop, and B was me on my desktop - but presumably talking to each other via some server in microsoft land - no cheating by talking direct!

elements.text: was referring to by "web interface". When I experimented with Live Share, user A generates a hyperlink that they send to user B, who clicks on the hyperlink in an email. That causes the desktop version of VSCode to launch on user B's machine. Then users A and user B both have desktop VSCode and can both see what each other is up to. Seems great but I haven't tried it with an actual "student". And for me, A was me on my laptop, and B was me on my desktop - but presumably talking to each other via some server in microsoft land - no cheating by talking direct!

text: In <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IdhnP00Y1Ks> I actually used Live Share with one instance in a web browser, and a second instance connecting from a desktop client. Both had the Julia extension loaded. Now back for that video I used VS Codespaces, which has now been shutdown because the new thing is GitHub Codespaces, but I would assume that this should work equally well with GitHub Codespaces.

Now back for that video I used VS Codespaces, which has now been shutdown because the new thing is GitHub Codespaces, but I would assume that this should work equally well with GitHub Codespaces.

text: We should figure out, though how we can share things like the plot pane etc via Live Share as well. I think things like the workspace explorer are probably also not shared?

elements.text: We should figure out, though how we can share things like the plot pane etc via Live Share as well. I think things like the workspace explorer are probably also not shared?

attachments.title: vsls
attachments.text: Enables VS Code extensions to access Live Share capabilities.

text: seems like we'll have to do it ourselves

elements.text: seems like we'll have to do it ourselves

text: Before encountering Julia, I used R and therefore RStudio for a few years (was a love-hate thing, mostly hate). I think the RStudio developers must really have to "do it themselves" when adding functionality. So it was a great plan for Julia to leverage VSCode and to have the Juno +VSCode extension teams join forces. I guess what I'm trying to say is thanks for all your efforts, and don't get discouraged!

elements.text: Before encountering Julia, I used R and therefore RStudio for a few years (was a love-hate thing, mostly hate). I think the RStudio developers must really have to "do it themselves" when adding functionality. So it was a great plan for Julia to leverage VSCode and to have the Juno +VSCode extension teams join forces. I guess what I'm trying to say is thanks for all your efforts, and don't get discouraged!

text: A nice non-VSCode way to do that live sharing might be to use Tuple (<https://tuple.app/>). I’ve found it to be better than Zoom for pair programming, but (i) it’s not free (though there’s a trial version) and (ii) it’s currently mac OS only, though they’re working on a linux client

attachments.title: Tuple: The best pair programming app on macOS
attachments.text: Low latency, low CPU usage, no annoying UI chrome. Because programmers deserve better than a generic screen sharing tool.
attachments.fallback: Tuple: Tuple: The best pair programming app on macOS

elements.text: A nice non-VSCode way to do that live sharing might be to use Tuple (
). I’ve found it to be better than Zoom for pair programming, but (i) it’s not free (though there’s a trial version) and (ii) it’s currently mac OS only, though they’re working on a linux client

text:
<@U0160CXEY3Z> and I have used VS-Code live share a few times.
It's pretty remarkable.
Occasionally bugs out, mostly in how the REPL displays. Sometimes it decided to wrap at 50characters. Restarting REPL fixed it.
It feels like it's still in beta?

It's all in all pretty excellent though. Strong recommend.
